content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of tissue on a single slide, consistent with a lymph node dissection. There are approximately 8-9 ovoid structures with dense purple (basophilic) staining, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. Several of these nodes appear to be partially or completely replaced by a different-looking tissue, suggesting potential metastatic involvement. The overall impression is a search for positive lymph nodes in a cancer staging procedure.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed on one of the central lymph nodes. This particular node is not uniformly dark purple like a normal reactive node; instead, it has mottled areas of pale pink and white mixed with the dense lymphoid tissue. This pattern is highly suspicious for partial replacement by tumor. I would zoom into this specific area, at the interface between the residual lymphoid tissue and the paler region, to examine the cells in the paler area and determine if they are metastatic carcinoma cells infiltrating the sinuses or if it's a benign process like sinus histiocytosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to systematically examine every lymph node submitted for evaluation. I have chosen to zoom into this specific area, which is part of one of the larger lymph nodes in the lower portion of the slide, to begin my high-power assessment. My goal is to carefully inspect the lymph node parenchyma, including the sinuses and follicular structures, for any atypical cells or glandular formations that would be indicative of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, after identifying several obviously positive large lymph nodes, the next step is to meticulously examine all submitted tissue to find every single positive node for accurate staging. The area in the green box represents a small, subtle aggregate of lymphoid cells within the perinodal fat in the lower right quadrant. It is crucial to zoom in on such small potential nodes to determine if they are also involved by the metastatic tumor, as even small deposits are significant for staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to systematically evaluate each lymph node for the presence of metastasis. This particular lymph node, although smaller than some others, exhibits the same suspicious features seen at low power: an expanded, dark cellular infiltrate. It is crucial to examine every node, regardless of size, to accurately determine the N stage. I need to confirm at high magnification whether these dark areas consist of malignant cells or are merely reactive lymphoid hyperplasia. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it represents one of the largest lymph nodes on the slide (the first major node from the top right). Its architecture appears almost completely replaced by a dense, basophilic cellular population, rather than showing the typical follicular and sinusoidal pattern of a reactive or normal lymph node. This solid, dark appearance is a classic sign that warrants high-magnification review for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary goal is to find any positive lymph nodes. This requires a systematic examination of every lymph node on the slide. I have zoomed into this particular area because it is one of the lymph nodes present in the specimen (one of the smaller, central nodes). The goal is to assess its architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification to look for non-native cells, such as clusters of atypical epithelial cells, which would indicate metastasis from a colorectal carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it shows one of the lymph nodes that appears heavily infiltrated at low magnification. The goal is to examine the cellular details of the dense, dark-staining population to confirm if it is metastatic carcinoma. This specific area allows me to view the interface between the dense cellular aggregate and the surrounding connective tissue/lymph node capsule, which is important for assessing the extent of involvement and potential extracapsular extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there are two distinct cell populations. There are aggregates of small, dark, round cells which are residual lymphocytes native to the lymph node. Infiltrating the sinuses and spaces between these lymphocytes are clusters and nests of larger, atypical cells. These cells have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, larger irregular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and are attempting to form poorly-defined glandular structures. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma infiltrating the lymphatic sinuses.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is extensively effaced and replaced by large, back-to-back nests of malignant cells. These cells exhibit significant pleomorphism, with large, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei. There are areas with a cribriform or glandular pattern. In the background, there is prominent necrosis and hemorrhage. The remaining native lymphocytes are pushed to the periphery. My impression is unequivocal for metastatic adenocarcinoma. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a small lymph node that is heavily infiltrated by a malignant tumor. The normal lymphoid architecture is largely effaced by a dense population of atypical, basophilic cells. These malignant cells are not only within the lymph node parenchyma but are also clearly infiltrating the surrounding adipose tissue (extranodal extension). My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic carcinoma showing extranodal extension.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is largely effaced. It is replaced by infiltrating nests and irregular aggregates of malignant cells with dark, pleomorphic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. These cells are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The remaining spaces are filled with eosinophilic necrotic debris and red blood cells within dilated sinuses. My impression is definitive: this is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I see that the normal lymph node parenchyma is almost completely effaced. It is replaced by dense, back-to-back nests and sheets of malignant cells. The tumor cells are relatively small, with dark (hyperchromatic), round nuclei, and scant cytoplasm, characteristic of a poorly differentiated carcinoma. The intervening stroma is scant, and there are areas of pale pink, acellular material consistent with tumor necrosis. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, extensively involved by metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node. The tissue is composed of dense, nodular aggregates of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, forming lymphoid follicles. The overall architecture of this portion of the lymph node appears preserved. I do not see any definite nests of atypical glandular cells or large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a reactive or benign lymph node, negative for metastasis. However, the entire lymph node must be scanned carefully, particularly the subcapsular sinus, before a final determination can be made.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see that the normal architecture of the lymph node is effaced and replaced by a malignant infiltrate. There are poorly formed glandular structures and solid nests composed of atypical cells with large, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These malignant cells are intermingled with a dense lymphoid population and areas of hemorrhage. The impression is definitive for a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma.
